Graphical abstract Oxidation of styrene into styrene oxide and benzaldehyde over Cu-doped layered double hydroxide through the metal-poxo pathway (1) and radical route (2). Copper(II) ions are inserted into brucite-like sheets in the Zn-Cu-Al ternary hydroxides via the precipitation route. The amount of octahedral Cu(II) sites in the Zn-Al(OH) interlayers depends on the copper loadings. The square-planar configuration (CuO) was observed in the high-copper content samples. The Cu-inserted zinc aluminum hydroxides have lamellar structure, modest surface area, and hexagonally uniform plate-like particles. All synthesized hydroxides were tested for the liquid-phase oxidation of styrene. The overall conversion of styrene obtained about 60–80 % and styrene oxide selectivity is about 70 %. The catalytic activity is correlated with the electronic configurations of copper(II) ions and reaction variables. The copper(II) ions in the brucite-like sheets proceeded through the oxidation of styrene following the metal-superpoxo pathway while the extra-lattice copper(II) ions underwent reaction with free radical route. The experimental results also indicated Cu-intercalated layered double hydroxide catalysts are more active than copper(II) oxide in the liquid-phase oxidation of styrene under the same conditions. Keywords Zn-Cu-Al Layered double hydroxide Metal-poxo Styrene Styrene oxide 1 Introduction Epoxidation of styrene is always an attractive reaction since it can provide an important fine chemical styrene oxide in addition to some other valuable oxygenated compounds. However, styrene epoxide was one of the most attractive intermediates because it is widely used for producing ultraviolet absorbents, epoxy resin- diluting agents, pharmaceutical-chemistry [1,2]. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous processes have been applied for the liquid- and gas- phase oxidation of olefins into epoxides. In general, homogeneous reaction usually produces a large number of waste byproducts which need further purification steps of products and the post-synthesis treatment [1,3]. For example, transition metal oxides or heavy metal salts were applied for the homogeneous oxidation reaction of hydrocarbons and discharged into environments inorganic salts (chromate, manganate, chlorinated-compounds…) [3–5]. Also, these oxidants and byproducts always cause corrosion and give low atom efficiency in chemical processes. Recent environmental and green chemistry principles require more selective chemical processes and phase out the aforementioned environmental issues [6]. Therefore, metal-catalyzed heterogeneous oxidation becomes more attractive in chemistry point of view [7]. The latter mainly uses a mixed transition oxide because of their easy recycling and highly catalytic stability under oxidative conditions. Subsequently, a large number of transition metals (Pt, Pd, Co, Ni, Cu, Au, Mo, V…) - containing catalysts have been reported in the literature for oxidation of olefins. These metals may be present in the forms of oxides loaded on the supports [8] or add in to a well-defined structure such as zeolites [9,10], spinels [11,12], mesoporous materials [13], metal -organic frameworks [14,15], layered structural solids [16–19]. In several cases, some catalysts expressed a low activity and low selectivity for the production of epoxide because they also promoted the decomposition of oxidizing agents and catalyzed the oxidation in different reaction pathways [1,2,6,13,14]. Layered double hydroxide (LDH) is a family of ionic natural clay-like materials with the general formula of [A2+ 1-xB3+ x(OH)2]Yn− x/n·mH2O, where A2+ and B3+ are metal cations in the brucite-like sheets; and Yn− is an anion intercalated between two consecutive hydroxide layers [16–20]. The existence of two di- and trivalent cations in the layers gives rise to imbalanced charges in the materials and a synergetic interaction between these cations makes the appearance of abnormal reduction – oxidation properties. Among transition metals-catalyzed epoxidations, copper-containing systems were paid much attention because they are commonly present in enzymes and metalorganic catalysts for the oxidation of hydrocarbons [2,11,14]. A numerous reaction mechanisms have been postulated for the oxidation of olefins and alcohols over Cu-based catalysts, but the roles of copper ions are still a debate subject [20–23]. From chemical kinetic point of view, taking account into the structure of transition state involving Cu-based catalysts gives us an idea to develop some more selective transition metal-catalyzed oxidation processes [1,2,7,13,22]. Follow this way, the design and preparation of heterogeneous catalysts with transition metal ions in the layered double hydroxide structure and the content of the surface hydroxide groups will be reactive for the oxidation of styrene. In previous studies, we have reported some transition metals- doped Mg- Al hydrotalcites for the oxidation of alcohols, hydrocarbons [16,18,20,22]. Their catalytic performance is strongly related with the location of transition metal cations, textural properties and the catalyst morphology. The present work deals with the preparation of new catalyst composition for the selective oxidation of styrene and the exploitation of the oxidation reaction pathway of styrene on Cu-containing catalysts. Both copper(II) and zinc(II) ions are immobilized in the brucite-like sheets of zinc aluminum hydroxides [21]. Since the electronic configuration of Zn2+ is d10, this makes an easily isomorphous substitution of Mg2+ with Zn2+ in the brucite-like sheets. Furthermore, a mutual interaction between Zn-Cu-Al at the atomic distance results in a high selectivity to the epoxide product. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation and characterization of the catalysts Zn–Cu-Al hydrotalcite-like ternary with carbonate as a guest inorganic anion was prepared from corresponding nitrate salt (Sigma Aldrich) solutions with different molar ratios of Zn2+/Cu2+/Al3+ in 25 mL of 0.60 M Na2CO3. The liquid phase was quantitatively analyzed by a gas chromatograph – mass spectrometer combination (Hewlett-Packard model 6890) with a HP-5 capillary column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characteristics Table 1 reported a series of Zn0.7-xCuxAl0.3(OH)2(CO3)0.15.mH2O samples prepared with x = 0 – 0.70 and their lattice parameters. The phase and crystalline structure of the as-prepared solids are investigated by X-ray diffraction method. Fig. 1 indicates no significant differentiation in X-ray diffractodiagrams between TD00 (Zn-Al layered double hydroxide) and TD01-TD04 patterns (Zn-Cu-Al samples). The sharp peaks at 2-thera of 11.61, 23.39, 34.93, 39.34, 46.33, 52.47, and 55.99° are respectively indexed for the reflection signals of (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110), and (113) crystal planes in the layered double hydroxide phase [18,24,25]. All reflection lines in XRD patterns of Zn-Cu-Al samples (TD01-TD04) are almost matched with those of the copper-free sample (TD00) as shown in Fig. 1. This result may originate from a close resemblance between Zn2+ (74 pm) and Cu2+ (73 pm) ionic radius. Thereby, the average distance of cation-cation in octahedral sheet (a) is expected almost unchanged in series of Zn0.7-xCuxAl0.3(OH)2(CO3)0.15 (Table 1) since Zn2+ ions were isomorphously substituted with Cu2+ in the octahedral sheets. A slight change in the height of the layered double hydroxide sheet and the interlayer space (c) is explained by the Jahn-Teller effect of Cu2+ ions in distorted octahedral structure, the nature of guest, ions electrostatic interaction between interlayer anions and lamellar cations [17,24–27]. In high-copper content samples, a remarkable number of copper(II) ions are present in the extra- layered hydroxide framework of Zn-Al(OH). Indeed, XRD pattern of the Zn- free sample (TD05) appears some reflection lines charactering for the phases of CuO, AlOOH and Cu-Al(OH) layered double hydroxide [25,25,26,27]. A set of reflection lines at (2-theta of 35.76, 38.49, and 47.82° are respectively indexed for the planes of (111), (002), and (202) while a weak signal of 38.75° is attributed to the (031) plane for AlOOH. The other reflection lines are characteristic for the Cu-Al(OH) solid. Infrared spectra of some representative samples before and after reaction were collected to investigate the presence of carbonate ions in the interlamellar region. All spectra of Zn-Cu-Al LDHs (TD01-TD05) are similar to the-one of Zn-Al layered compound (TD00), implying the successful preparation of Cu-intercalated layered hydroxide compounds. A broad band at 3464 cm−1 was assigned for the stretching vibrational mode of adsorbed water molecules in the solid [18,21,22,26]. More attention was paid to the weaker band at 1620 cm−1 which is attributed to the OH bending vibration of water species located in the gallery [26,28]. A very sharp band at 1365 cm−1 is assigned to the asymmetric stretching mode of carbonate anions in the confined interlayer spaces [29,30]. For a set of weaker band in the region of 400−1000 cm-1, a broad band at 748 cm-1 comes from the vibrational modes of OH groups, and a weak shoulder at 835 cm-1 results from the bending motion of carbonate anions in the interlayer domain. An absorption band at 545 cm-1 is ascribed to the Zn-O vibration in the octahedral sheets and disappears in the FT-IR spectrum of the Zn-free sample (TD05). The three observable bands at 605, 547, and 424 cm-1 are ascribed to the lattice translational modes of metal – oxygen bond (Fig. 2 ). Thus, FT-IR spectra reaffirm the presence of carbonate guest ions between the Zn-Cu-Al double hydroxide layers. The oxidation states and environmental coordination of each element in the as-synthesized solids are investigated by UV–vis spectroscopy and XPS technique. Fig. 3 exhibits UV–vis spectra of Cu-inserted catalysts and Zn-free sample (TD05). The profile shapes of two Zn-Cu-Al layered double hydroxides are quite analogous, implying good distribution of Cu(II) ions in these compounds. It is also noticeable that the shape of UV–vis spectrum of the spent catalyst is almost familiar with that of fresh-one, reflecting the high stability of Zn-Cu-Al catalysts in the oxidative conditions. Lastly, a band around 250 nm is assigned to the transition of d8 electron – electron of Cu2+-O bond the O2− → Cu2+ ligand to metal charge transfer transition. This band gradually shifts to a longer wavelength as copper content increases because of the existence of different forms of Cu2+ ions in the sample, in line with the XRD analysis. A second band in the range of 425–475 nm did not monitor clearly on sample TD01-TD02, but became more visualization in samples TD03-TD05. This band involves in the characteristic absorption of Cu(II) oxide particles. A third band in the range of 650–800 nm is ascribed to the transition of d-d in Cu-intercalated hydroxide layers [21]. This result is supported by a gradual decrease of such absorption band intensity on sample TD05. More information of these ions and surface chemistry would be elucidated after examining XPS data. Fig. 4 a presents XPS survey of three as-prepared layered double hydroxides with elemental compositions and binding energies. XPS spectrum of sample TD05 shows no Zn element in the sample (Table 1). Fig. 4b displays Al(III) 2p3/2 scan of three different samples. The two broad peaks are attributed to the existence of different Al3+ species in a sample, thus they are deconvoluted and represented as doted lines in Fig. 4b. The highest intensity peak located at 75.3–75.7 eV in all samples and the two others centered at 78.0–78.5 eV and 79.4–79.8 eV. The low intensity of high binding energy peaks is explained by a very low amount of the non-brucite-like framework aluminum ions in the Zn-containing samples (T01-TD03, Table 1). Since binding energy values of Cu2+ species are higher than that of CuO (about 933.5 eV), the peak at 936.2 eV with the satellite at 943.9 eV is firmly attributed to the Cu2+ 2p3/2 species in the framework of Cu-doped minerals [27,28,31]. The most attention here is that binding energy of Zn 2p3/2 is higher than that in ZnO. This chemical shift herein comes from the structure effects of Zn2+ in LDH. The oxygen in the brucite-like layer (Me-O) has the binding energy of 535.5 eV [22,31]. All spectral investigation indicates the formation of layered double hydroxide phase and the partial substitution of Zn2+ by Cu2+ in the brucite-like sheets. A higher copper content is in the sample (TD03 - TD05); the more extra-lattice Cu2+ species is present in the samples. The catalyst morphology was reported in Fig. 5 . SEM and TEM images of Cu-doped samples before and after oxidation reaction of styrene with t-BuOOH were recorded. For TD03 sample, it was observed a pack of uniform plate-like particles with the thickness of 50−60 nm. The plate surface is rather smooth and the diameter is in the range of 200–300 nm. These plates are arranged random, resulting in the formation of voids between interparticles. No remarkable difference in catalyst morphology between the fresh sample and used catalysts (Fig. 5a and 5b), inferring a good structural stability of Zn-Cu-Al catalyst system under oxidation reaction conditions. Fig. 5c also reveals that the Cu-rich sample (TD05) has smaller plates, but these particles are closely packed together and less smooth surface, possibly due to the presence of amorphous hydroxides. TEM images show the hexagonal shape of Zn-Cu-Al particles which is typically characteristic for layered double hydroxide materials. Both spent and fresh samples show the lamellar structure and similar closest packings. For the Zn-free sample, the particles of the as-synthesized sample become more rounded with smaller diameters. This may result from the low crystalline degree of the Cu-Al samples precipitated at constant pH condition, in good harmony with the nitrogen physisorption measurements in which the surface area of reacted sample is on par with that of fresh catalyst (Fig. S2 in Supplementary Materials). 3.2 Catalytic activity The oxidation of styrene normally breaks the π-bond in vinyl group to produce oxygenated aromatic products although in some cases the opening aromatic-ring oxidation reaction was observed. The selectivity to products was dependent on the nature of catalysts, oxidants, and reaction variables [6–9,11–16,32,33]. In the present work, a set of the same experiments was carried out over Zn-Cu-Al LDH samples. In addition, two reference experiments were performed on a physically mixed ZnO-CuO-AlO3 and blank test (without catalyst) for comparison. In all cases the obtained products are styrene oxide, benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, phenyl acetaldehyde, phenyl glycol… in which styrene oxide was a major component. The activity of catalyst series (TD00-TD05) was represented in Fig. 6 . The blank test gives the lowest conversion of styrene into styrene epoxide and benzaldehyde. The conversion of substrate slightly increases when a given amount of Cu-free catalyst (TD00) or ZnO-CuO-Al2O3 (Oxid) was present in the reaction mixture. Furthermore, Cu-containing catalysts express a higher conversion of styrene, especially Cu2+ ions in the Zn-Al layered double hydroxide solids (TD01-TD04). Indeed, styrene conversion on TD01-TD05 catalysts increases approximately 3–4 times as much as the mixed CuO-ZnO-AlO3 catalyst (Fig. 6). Herein, the styrene conversion is proportional to the amount of copper (II) ions in the intra-brucite-like sheets. The selectivity to styrene epoxide decreases insignificantly from sample TD01 to TD05 while that to byproduct exhibits an opposite trend. Thus, the product distribution may be correlated with the amount and position of Cu2+ species in the catalysts. While the intra-hydroxide interlayer copper(II) sites play as principal sites for the selective formation of styrene oxide, the tiny CuO particles facilitate for the production of both styrene oxide and benzaldehyde [9,33,34]. A high activity of Cu-doped layered double hydrotalcite catalysts may also result from the synergetic effect between the two transition metal ions, Zn2+ and Cu2+ in the interlayer sheets and the electron density of Cu2+ active sites. On the contrary, sample TD05 has a portion of CuO agglomerates which gives rise to a lower activity. Of these catalyst batches, the TD03-TD04 catalysts are herein an appropriate composition for the oxidation of styrene to styrene oxide. The effect of various reaction parameters was screened in terms of styrene conversion, selectivity, and yield of styrene oxide and benzaldehyde. Reaction temperature is always an important factor in the epoxidation reaction because the reactant is an active monomer that easily converts into many products. Fig. 7 shows a linear increase in styrene conversion in the reaction temperature range of 60−80 °C. Both substrate conversion and styrene epoxide selectivity increases with increasing reaction temperature while benzaldehyde selectivity decreases slightly, suggesting that the two products may be produced in parallel [35]. As compared with benzaldehyde, styrene oxide was favorably yielded at high temperatures under the same experimental conditions [34,35]. Simultaneously, a remarkable amount of byproducts is formed at high reaction temperatures. It is noted that the over-oxidation of intermediate products and isomerization of styrene oxide into phenyl acetaldehyde both were promoted on Lewis acid sites at high reaction temperatures [17,22,32,36]. At 80 °C, selectivity to the desired products is till rather high at styrene conversion about 70 %. Thus, the prolongation of reaction time would convert more styrene into oxygenated products. Fig. 8 reports a variation of conversion and product selectivity versus reaction time on catalyst TD03. The substrate conversion increases from 44.7–93.1 % in the reaction time range of 2–8 h. At the first glance, styrene oxide and benzaldehyde selectivities both likely reduce while byproduct selectivities increase slightly as the reaction was prolonged from 4 to 8 h. This phenomenon was explained by two hypotheses: (i) an occurrence of some side reaction towards the production of byproducts at the expense of styrene and benzaldehyde or (ii) the direct formation of byproducts from styrene under present reaction conditions. As an illustration, two other catalysts (TD01 and TD05) were also tested at different reaction times and the two wanted product yields are reported in Fig. 9 (and Fig. S3 and S4). The yield of styrene epoxide is proportional to substrate conversion during the reaction course. Meanwhile, the yield of benzaldehyde fluctuates with reaction time and copper(II) content in the catalysts. This observation affirms that benzaldehyde may participate in the deep-oxidation reaction to form benzoic acid [17,19,30,33]. In addition, benzaldehyde was favorably produced on the Cu-rich samples (Fig. 9b), meaning that the formation of benzaldehyde may not depend on the location of copper(II) ions in the catalysts. Examining effects of reaction time on the product distribution brings valuable information on the reaction pathway. Further step would concentrate on the reaction pathway of the styrene oxidation. A set of experiments was carried out with different molar ratios of oxidant/substrate at a constant temperature. It is clearly observed that styrene conversion is linearly proportional to the amount of oxidant added. At a low molar ratio of t-BuOOH/styrene, the oxidant is a limiting agent so that a low conversion of styrene is understandable. This observation strongly supports the assumption that the two products (benzaldehyde and styrene epoxide) are produced in different ways [22,23,27,30,31]. Although styrene oxide selectivity likely obtains a maximum at the molar ratio of 2, the styrene oxide yield still remains a constant, reflecting that styrene oxide yield was not affected in excess of oxidant (t-BuOOH/styrene of 2–4). Most notable was a change in benzaldehyde selectivity. In theory, the stoichiometric coefficient number of styrene: t-BuOOH is 1: 2 in the overall chemical equation of benzaldehyde production, therefore the benzaldehyde selectivity was low in the molar ratio range of 0.5 - 2.0. Fig. 10 reveals a higher selectivity to benzaldehyde in an excess of t-BuOOH in the reaction mixture, thank to either the production of benzaldehyde over different active sites or the conversion of styrene oxide into benzaldehyde under present reaction conditions [15,18,21,32]. It is already stated that copper(II) ions exist at least in two different co-ordinations of Cu2+ ions at the octahedral sites and in the square-planar configuration (CuO). In order to elucidate the role of each component in the present oxidation reactions, a given amount of radical inhibitor, 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methyl phenol (BMP), was added in the reaction mixture at different reaction times. Four sets of experiments are carried out at the same conditions in the presence of radical scavenger. Firstly, a mixed ZnO-CuO-Al2O3 shows a negligible styrene conversion as the inhibitor was added into the reaction flask (Exp. 1, Fig. 11 ) while it expresses much higher activity in the absence of BMP (Fig. 6), suggesting that the oxidation of styrene occurs in the radical route on copper(II) oxide particles. Secondly, two other series of experiments were simultaneously carried out in the presence and absence of the radical inhibitor at different reaction times over sample TD01. Interestingly, the presence of BMP did not totally inhibit the oxidation reaction of styrene with t-BuOOH over Cu-doped layered double hydroxide catalyst (Fig. 11). In detail, substrate conversion and styrene oxide yield are respectively about 38.9 and 29.8 % (Fig. 9) over TD01 sample in the absence of inhibitor, but decline to 19.6 and 13.6 % in the presence of radical scavenger (Exp2, Fig. 11). A decrease of styrene conversion (19.3 %) between the former and latter case is proximately equivalent to the styrene conversion of 18 % obtained on ZnO-CuO-Al2O3 (Oxid) sample (Fig. 6). Herein, a logical explanation was given by the fact that TD01 has some tiny particles of CuO which undergo the oxidation of styrene through the radical pathway. Furthermore, an increased amount of radical scavenger has no remarkable effect on the oxidation of styrene (Exp3, Fig. 11). In another experiment, the oxidation of reaction of styrene with t-BuOOH was lasted for 2 h and then the inhibitor was added into the mixture (Exp4*, Fig.11), both styrene conversion and the main product yield are a remarkable increment as compared to those of the reaction run for 2 h in the presence of radical inhibitor (Exp2, Fig. 11). Similarly, the reaction has a very high conversion of styrene as prolonged for 4 h prior to addition of inhibitor (Exp5**, Fig. 11), asserting that two types of the oxidation reaction happen in parallel on different active sites [36–38]. The radical- pathway reaction was prohibited while the other kept going in the presence of BMP. Fig. 11 also pointed out that sample TD05 (Zn-free sample) shows a modest conversion of styrene although the inhibitor was added into the reaction mixture at beginning step. Indeed, TD05 is typically composed of both extra- and intra-octahedral framework copper(II) sites [7,11,13,22,23,34]. Analysis of reactivity of Cu-doped layered double hydroxides and a mixed ZnO-CuO-Al2O3 in the presence and absence of radical inhibitor (BMP) let us suggest plausible reaction pathways on CuO and the Cu-doped layered double hydroxides. The oxidation of styrene takes place through the non-radical route on the intra-brucite-like sheet Cu2+ sites and (ii) the radical pathway on single copper(II) oxide [11,39,40]. It was known that transitional metals fixed in a well–defined structure may form the metal-complex intermediate via the adsorption and coordination with t-BuOOH [25,26,30], which can further interact with an adsorbed styrene molecule to yield a styrene oxide molecule. Meanwhile, copper oxide particles provide active sites for the radical pathway which is substantiated by the catalytic activity of ZnO-CuO-Al2O3 (Oxid) sample. The formation of styrene epoxide was proposed through multiple consecutive reactions (Scheme 1 ). First of all, the middle oxygen in t-butyl hydrogen peroxide makes a coordination to an intra-lattice Cu2+ ion in the octahedral layers while hydrogen atom in t-BuOOH is attached to a neighboring zinc(II)-oxygen. The proximity between zinc(II), copper (II), and Al(III) ions in the hydrotalcite-like structure is perquisite for the formation of such a metal-peroxo complex. Substrate molecules diffuse into interlayer regions and absorb on the brucite-like sheet surface. Subsequently, am absorbed styrene reacts with copper(II)-hydroperoxo intermediate (2) to form the alkenyl copper(II)-peroxo complex (3) and then a t-BuOH molecule was liberated. Finally, the decomposition of the copper(II)-superoxo complex (3) gives a styrene oxide molecule and the Cu2+-catalytic center was recycled. In a similar way, benzaldehyde production requires two equivalent moles of t-BuOOH and proceeds according to Scheme 2 . A low selectivity to benzaldehyde may result from the steric hindrance of t-butyl and phenyl groups in copper(II)-peroxo intermediate (4′) in the confined interlayer region (Scheme 2) [11,38]. For the extra-lattice Cu2+ ions (CuO, Cu(OH)2..), the function of copper(II) oxide serves as active sites for the decomposition of t-BuOOH into t-butyl peroxyl radicals via one electron transfer, wherein Cu2+ species are reduced to Cu+ ion and generate a radical t-BuOO . Then, a t-butoxyl radical attacks to vinyl group in styrene to make a peroxide intermediate, which further decomposes into a styrene oxide and a t-butoxyl radical (t-BuO ) and a styrene oxide. The latter radical takes an electron from Cu(I) ions to form a t-butyl alcohol and recycles a Cu(II) site [11,34,38–41]. Thus, the presence of BMP would inhibit the propagation reaction. The proposed pathway is presented in Scheme 3 . Since the catalytic activity was strongly affected by the appearance of inhibitor or any other radical impurities, the catalyst stability should be considered carefully for the oxidation of styrene with t-BuOOH on Cu-doped layered double hydroxide catalysts. Sample TD03 was collected after reaction termination and washed with ethanol prior to drying in an oven. The recycled sample was tested for the oxidation of styrene with t-BuOOH under the same conditions and the experimental results are reported in Fig. 12 . Cu-doped LDH catalyst expresses a good reusability under oxidative conditions. The conversion slightly decreases about 4–6 % after the first reaction then insignificantly changes after four recyclings. After the first reaction, a marginal decrease of catalytic activity is likely due to the removal of some tiny CuO particles located on the LDH surface, which makes a better visual morphology of catalysts as indicated in Figs. 3 and 5 [33,34,37]. A similar result was observed when the catalyst was applied for four consecutive tests. While Cu2+ ions are fixed in the octahedral sites, they become stabilized and highly favored in the catalytic oxidation of styrene into styrene oxide and benzaldehyde. 4 Conclusions Cu-based catalysts with different metal composition of Zn, Cu, Al are prepared by the co-precipitation method. The main component of as synthesized solids is Zn-Cu-Al layered double hydroxide and small amount of corresponding metal oxides. The amount of extra- lattice copper(II) ions is dependent on the molar ratios of Zn/Cu/Al and preparation conditions… The Cu-doped zinc aluminum hydroxides have layered double hydroxide structure, modest surface area, and uniform plate-like particles. Cu2+ ions located in the brucite-like sheets are octahedral geometry while the non- layered hydroxide framework copper(II) ions are in the square-planar configuration. All synthesized hydroxides were used as heterogeneous catalysts for the liquid-phase oxidation of styrene. Our experimental results indicated that the copper ions at octahedral sites in the brucite-like hydroxide layers perform the oxidation of styrene through the metal-superpoxo complex pathway while CuO performed the reaction via the radical route. In both cases, styrene oxide is always a main product. The overall conversion of styrene obtained about 60–80 % with high selectivity to styrene oxide. coredata.dc:description: Copper(II) ions are inserted into brucite-like sheets in the Zn-Cu-Al ternary hydroxides via the precipitation route. The amount of octahedral Cu(II) sites in the Zn-Al(OH) interlayers depends on the copper loadings. The square-planar configuration (CuO) was observed in the high-copper content samples. The Cu-inserted zinc aluminum hydroxides have lamellar structure, modest surface area, and hexagonally uniform plate-like particles. All synthesized hydroxides were tested for the liquid-phase oxidation of styrene. The overall conversion of styrene obtained about 60–80 % and styrene oxide selectivity is about 70 %. The catalytic activity is correlated with the electronic configurations of copper(II) ions and reaction variables. The copper(II) ions in the brucite-like sheets proceeded through the oxidation of styrene following the metal-superpoxo pathway while the extra-lattice copper(II) ions underwent reaction with free radical route. The experimental results also indicated Cu-intercalated layered double hydroxide catalysts are more active than copper(II) oxide in the liquid-phase oxidation of styrene under the same conditions.
